Hierarchical Personalized Federated Learning Over Massive Mobile Edge Computing Networks

Chaoqun You,  Kun Guo, 
Howard H. Yang  and Tony Q. S. Quek C. You and T. Q. S. Quek are with the Wireless Networks and Design Systems Group, Singapore University of Design and Technology, 487372, Singapore (e-mail: chaoqun_you, tonyquek@sutd.edu.sg).K. Guo is with the Shanghai Key Laboratory of Multidimensional Information Processing, School of Communications and Electronics Engineering, East China Normal University, Shanghai 200241, China (e-mail: kguo@cee.ecnu.edu.cn).H. H. Yang is with the Zhejiang University/University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign Institute, Zhejiang University, Haining 314400, China (email: haoyang@intl.zju.edu.cn).
Abstract

Personalized Federated Learning (PFL) is a new Federated Learning (FL) paradigm, particularly tackling the heterogeneity issues brought by various mobile user equipments (UEs) in mobile edge computing (MEC) networks. However, due to the ever-increasing number of UEs and the complicated administrative work it brings, it is desirable to switch the PFL algorithm from its conventional two-layer framework to a multiple-layer one. In this paper, we propose hierarchical PFL (HPFL), an algorithm for deploying PFL over massive MEC networks. The UEs in HPFL are divided into multiple clusters, and the UEs in each cluster forward their local updates to the edge server (ES) synchronously for edge model aggregation, while the ESs forward their edge models to the cloud server semi-asynchronously for global model aggregation. The above training manner leads to a tradeoff between the training loss in each round and the round latency. HPFL combines the objectives of training loss minimization and round latency minimization while jointly determining the optimal bandwidth allocation as well as the ES scheduling policy in the hierarchical learning framework. Extensive experiments verify that HPFL not only guarantees convergence in hierarchical aggregation frameworks but also has advantages in round training loss maximization and round latency minimization.

Index Terms:
PFL, hierarchical aggregation, massive MEC

I Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) is a distributed machine learning paradigm that enables multiple mobile user equipments (UEs) to jointly train a common model without ever uploading their raw data to a central parameter server (PS) [1]. FL has already shown its great potential in exploring behavior patterns hidden in the large amount of data generated by UEs, such as intelligent vehicles, smartphones, and wearable devices. These patterns, also known as model parameters, will provide guidance to newcomers, thus fostering significant applications such as Artificial Intelligence (AI) medical diagnosis [2] and autonomous vehicles [3]. Despite the tremendous benefits FL brings to edge intelligence, model training in heterogenous and potentially massive mobile edge computing (MEC) networks introduces novel challenges that require a fundamental departure from conventional approaches.

Conventionally, FL algorithms are implemented in a two-layer framework with a central PS and multiple distributed UEs [4, 5]. Using the on-device datasets, UEs train local models in reference to the current global model, which are then collected by the PS to further improve the global model. The PS will then feed the new model back to UEs for a new round of local updating. However, this typical two-layer framework does not scale well to large-scale FL settings, which are inevitable over massive MEC networks. This is because, (i) the communication and computation resources in a MEC system are limited [6, 7]. Direct communications between UEs and the remote PS will slow down the overall training due to the scarce resources allocated to each UE; (ii) the number of UEs ranges from thousands to billions. Such a humongous number of UEs makes it hard for the PS to manage and monitor the training process [8, 9]. Therefore, a two-layer framework is not enough, and a multi-layer FL framework emerges as a pragmatic solution for large-scale FL implementation in practice [10, 11, 12].

In addition, datasets generated by UEs are characterized by a high degree of diversity [13, 14, 15]. Not only does the number of data samples generated by UEs vary, but these data samples are not independent and identically distributed (non-i.i.d). Learning from such heterogeneous data is difficult, as conventional FL algorithms usually develop a common model for all UEs such that the obtained global model could perform arbitrarily poorly on a specific UE. This situation worsens with the rapid development of end-user devices’ sensing and computation capabilities. Therefore, it is desired for the FL algorithm to provide personalized services to individual UEs by conducting adaptations to the global model.

Despite the extensive studies on personalized algorithms of FL, remarkably little is known about their implementations in a hierarchical framework. Specifically, [16] proposed the first work in providing personalized FL services to UEs, named Personalized Federated Learning (PFL). It is an approach that learns an initial model that is good enough for all UEs to start with. Using this initial model, each UE can conduct fast adaptation to its local dataset using only a few data points. As a result, the UEs can enjoy fast personalized models by adapting the global model to local datasets. From PFL, a string of follow-ups [17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22] modified, developed and extended PFL. However, their focus has been primarily on a two-layer or non-hierarchical FL framework. It is unclear how to implement PFL in a hierarchical framework, considering limited communication and computational resources in MEC networks, and whether PFL can converge with such an implementation.

In this paper, we propose a PFL algorithm for massive MEC networks, named hierarchical PFL (HPFL), which conducts fast adaptations with hierarchical aggregations. As illustrated in Fig. 1, HPFL considers a learning framework that consists of three layers, i.e., the UE, edge server (ES), and central server (CS) layers. Each ES, which serves multiple UEs and can be co-located with small cell base stations, synchronously aggregates local models that are trained and sent by UEs. The CS is connected to a macro base station, semi-asynchronously aggregates edge models that are sent by ESs. More specifically, after receiving the current global model, UEs train and update their local models using their datasets. The updated local models are then transmitted to the ES for synchronous edge aggregation. Then, the updated edge models are further transmitted to the CS for semi-asynchronous global model aggregation and update. The updated global model will then be sent back to individual UEs in the same way they came. A full round of this procedure constitutes one communication round, and the system repeats such interactions until HPFL converges. With hierarchical aggregations, limited resources are released to serve more UEs, making it much easier for the HPFL scheduler to manage the massive MEC networks.

The semi-asynchronous training across ESs leads to a tradeoff between the per round training loss and the round latency over resource-limited MEC networks. To that end, our objective is to minimize the weighted sum of the round training loss and the round latency by jointly optimizing ES scheduling policy and bandwidth allocation. To make the formulated optimization problem tractable, we first analyze the convergence of HPFL. Based on the analysis results, we decompose the optimization problem as a separate ES scheduling problem and bandwidth allocation problem and solve them, respectively. With the obtained results, we can implement HPFL over MEC networks to provide efficient hierarchical training services.

To summarize, in this paper, we make the following contributions:

  • •

    We develop HPFL, a three-layer FL framework that supports hierarchical aggregations. Specifically, the ES and its UEs conduct synchronous training, while the ESs and CS carry out semi-asynchronous training. By solving a joint ES scheduling and bandwidth allocation problem, HPFL seeks an efficient tradeoff between providing the maximum round training loss and the minimum round latency.

  • •

    We derive the convergence rate of HPFL for non-convex loss functions. Our analysis shows that the upper bound of the training loss in each round is a linear function of data importance, thus allowing us to reformulate the round training loss maximization problem to the data importance maximization problem.

  • •

    We solve the reformulated optimization problem by decoupling it into two sub-problems: an ES scheduling problem and a bandwidth allocation problem. Particularly, the ES scheduling problem can be solved by comparing the value of total data importance captured in each round with the value of round latency, while the optimal bandwidth allocation can also be achieved using an online algorithm.

  • •

    We conduct extensive experiments using the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets to verify the effectiveness of HPFL in saving the round latency as well as capturing more important data, compared with intuitive HFL and HPFL algorithms with fully selected or randomly selected ESs.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section II we review two algorithms, hierarchical FL (HFL) and PFL, to introduce some basic ideas and notations that will be used in our proposed algorithm. Then in Section III and Section IV we introduce the system model and problem formulation of HPFL. In order to solve the optimization problem of HPFL, we first analyze its convergence in Section V, and then, in Section VI, we decompose the problem as a separate ES scheduling problem and a bandwidth allocation problem, and solve them, respectively. At last, we evaluate the performance of HPFL through extensive experiments in Section VII and conclude this work in Section VIII.

II Backgrounds

This section reviews the notations and concepts in HFL and PFL algorithms to facilitate the design of our algorithm.

II-A Hierarchical Federated Learning

Implementing FL in a small area (e.g., companies or hospitals) usually considers a two-tier architecture, where there is a central server and n𝑛n UEs. The target for the learner is to find the optimal model parameter 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} that minimizes the loss function f​(𝐰)=1n​∑i=1nfi​(𝐰)𝑓𝐰1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰f(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(\mathbf{w}) across all UEs, where fi​(𝐰)subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰f_{i}(\mathbf{w}) denotes the loss function of UE i𝑖i in predicting model parameter 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}. That is, the goal for all the entities is to obtain 𝐰∗=arg⁡min𝐰⁡f​(𝐰)superscript𝐰subscript𝐰𝑓𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*}=\arg\min_{\mathbf{w}}f(\mathbf{w}), while preserving privacy of all the UEs.

In practice, the optimal 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} is attained via T𝑇T rounds of training across the n𝑛n UEs. Specifically, at round t𝑡t, after receiving the global model parameter 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t}, each UE i𝑖i uses its local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} to update the local model according to the following

𝐰t+1i=𝐰t−β​∇fi​(𝐰t),superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡𝛽∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{i}=\mathbf{w}_{t}-\beta\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}), (1)

where β𝛽\beta denotes the learning rate. The updated local model parameter 𝐰t+1isuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑖\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{i} is then uploaded to and aggregated at the central server as 𝐰t+1=1n​∑i=1n𝐰t+1isubscript𝐰𝑡11𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑖\mathbf{w}_{t+1}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{i}. In this way, the global model progresses from 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t} to 𝐰t+1subscript𝐰𝑡1\mathbf{w}_{t+1}. This process is repeated until a certain model prediction accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is achieved.

Regarding large-scale learning tasks, HFL becomes a natural choice for collecting information from a swarm of mobile UEs. These edge nodes are divided into multiple small areas based on their geographical locations. The small areas are generally separated by tens of kilometers, and each small area contains thousands of UEs. Therefore, the hierarchical architecture for large-scale FL usually contains at least three tiers (cf. Fig. 1). Usually, an edge server is in charge of a small area, whereas UEs in this small area will train their local models and then send their updates to the edge server. The edge server aggregates local models and then updates its edge model. Formally, if there are nksubscript𝑛𝑘n_{k} UEs in a small area k𝑘k (k=1,2,…,K𝑘12…𝐾k=1,2,\dots,K), then the model aggregation at ES k𝑘k takes the following form

𝐰t+1k=1nk​∑i=1nk𝐰t+1k,i,superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘1subscript𝑛𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘𝑖\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{k}=\frac{1}{n_{k}}\sum_{i=1}^{n_{k}}\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{k,i}, (2)

where 𝐰t+1k,isuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘𝑖\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{k,i} denotes the updated local model at UE i𝑖i, and it is computed by

𝐰t+1k,i=𝐰tk,i−β​∇fi​(𝐰t).superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘𝑖𝛽∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{k,i}=\mathbf{w}_{t}^{k,i}-\beta\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}). (3)

Then, given K𝐾K small areas for large-scale FL, each ES will send its edge model to the cloud server for global model aggregation, which is computed as follows,

𝐰t+1=1K​∑k=1K𝐰t+1k.subscript𝐰𝑡11𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘\mathbf{w}_{t+1}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{k}. (4)

The main advantage of HFL lies in the significant reduction of communication resources since there exist no direct communications between individual UEs and the cloud server. Updates from individual UEs are uploaded layer by layer, thus greatly reducing the number of entities competing for bandwidth resources simultaneously.

II-B Personalized Federated Learning

PFL is proposed to address the mismatch problem between local and global models, which is essentially derived from the heterogeneous datasets generated by UEs. It uses the well-known meta-learning algorithm, MAML, to interpret FL. The target of PFL is to find a well-performed initial point that is easy for individual UEs to adapt to. Specifically, PFL aims to find a good initial point, or meta model 𝐰metasubscript𝐰meta\mathbf{w}_{\text{meta}}. Starting from 𝐰metasubscript𝐰meta\mathbf{w}_{\text{meta}}, each UE i𝑖i conducts a fast adaptation to its local dataset with only a few data points using only one or more steps of gradient descent and then obtains its local model, or fine-tuned model, 𝐰fine-tunedsubscript𝐰fine-tuned\mathbf{w}_{\text{fine-tuned}}.

Overall, the objective of the learner in PFL is to minimize the loss function F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F(\mathbf{w}) across all UEs, where Fi​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰F_{i}(\mathbf{w}) denotes the loss function of UE i𝑖i. Particularly, Fi​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰F_{i}(\mathbf{w}) is defined as follows,

Fi​(𝐰)=fi​(𝐰−α​∇fi​(𝐰)),subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰𝛼∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰F_{i}(\mathbf{w})=f_{i}(\mathbf{w}-\alpha\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w})), (5)

where α≥0𝛼0\alpha\geq 0 is the learning rate of individual UEs. Unlike conventional FL algorithms, after receiving the current global model 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t}, a UE in PFL first computes adapted/fine-tuned parameters θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} with one step of gradient descent, which is computed as follows,

θi=𝐰t−α​∇fi​(𝐰t).subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡𝛼∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\theta_{i}=\mathbf{w}_{t}-\alpha\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}). (6)

Then, based on θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i}, UE i𝑖i updates its local model parameter as follows:

𝐰t+1i=𝐰ti−β​∇𝐰Fi​(θi).superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖𝛽subscript∇𝐰subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{i}=\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i}-\beta\nabla_{\mathbf{w}}F_{i}(\theta_{i}). (7)

It is worthwhile to note that the gradient of Fi​(θi)subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖F_{i}(\theta_{i}) contains a Hessian matrix to 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t}, i.e.,

∇𝐰Fi​(θi)=(I−α​∇2fi​(𝐰t))​∇fi​(𝐰t−α​∇fi​(𝐰t)).subscript∇𝐰subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖𝐼𝛼superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡𝛼∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\nabla_{\mathbf{w}}F_{i}(\theta_{i})=(I-\alpha\nabla^{2}f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}))\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}-\alpha\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})). (8)

Finally, at the central server, the global model is updated with the following formula,

𝐰t+1=1n​∑i=1n𝐰t+1i=𝐰t−β​1n​∑i=1n∇𝐰Fi​(θi).subscript𝐰𝑡11𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡𝛽1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript∇𝐰subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖\mathbf{w}_{t+1}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{i}=\mathbf{w}_{t}-\beta\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\nabla_{\mathbf{w}}F_{i}(\theta_{i}). (9)

III System Model

In this paper, we consider implementing PFL in a hierarchical framework. With the same hierarchical architecture we introduce in HFL (see Fig. 1), we consider a set of K𝐾K ESs 𝒦={1,…,K}𝒦1…𝐾\mathcal{K}=\{1,\dots,K\}. They can be co-located with small cell base stations [23]. Each server k𝑘k has nksubscript𝑛𝑘n_{k} local UEs, denoted as 𝒩k={1,…,nk}subscript𝒩𝑘1…subscript𝑛𝑘\mathcal{N}_{k}=\{1,\dots,n_{k}\}. Meanwhile, the edge servers are connected with a macro base station, equipped with a cloud server, denoted by CS 00. Local models trained by individual UEs are first aggregated at edge servers before finally reaching the cloud server. We consider synchronous FL for the lower level of the hierarchy (i.e., FL between edge servers and mobile UEs) but semi-asynchronous FL for the higher level of the hierarchy (i.e., FL between the cloud server and edge servers). In this section, we introduce the system model following the learning process of model parameter generation and transmission.

III-A Local Model Training and Transmission

III-A1 Local Model Training

Under each edge server k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, local UE i𝑖i owns a local dataset 𝒟k,isubscript𝒟𝑘𝑖\mathcal{D}_{k,i}, and its size is denoted as Dk,i=|𝒟k,i|subscript𝐷𝑘𝑖subscript𝒟𝑘𝑖D_{k,i}=|\mathcal{D}_{k,i}|. Based on 𝒟k,isubscript𝒟𝑘𝑖\mathcal{D}_{k,i}, UE i𝑖i trains its local model using the iterative formula as follows,

𝐰t+1k,i=𝐰t−β​∇Fk,i​(𝐰t),superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡𝛽∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{k,i}=\mathbf{w}_{t}-\beta\nabla F_{k,i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}), (10)

where Fk,i​(𝐰t)subscript𝐹𝑘𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡F_{k,i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}) is the PFL loss function defined in (5) of UE i𝑖i under edge server k𝑘k at round t𝑡t. Then, UE i𝑖i sends 𝐰t+1k,isuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘𝑖\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{k,i} to its edge server k𝑘k. For simplicity of notation, we consider only one gradient update in the formula and for the rest of the paper, but using multiple local iterations is a straightforward extension. It is also worth noting that we use the full-batch gradient descent to update the local model. In practice, this is not the usual case. Schedulers are encouraged to sample mini-batch of data points on each UE since the volume of data generated by UEs is too large to be processed. While not the focus of this work, the analysis of mini-batch gradient decent can naturally be combined with the methods proposed herein.

As for the computation time of UE i𝑖i within the coverage of ES k𝑘k, let ck,isubscript𝑐𝑘𝑖c_{k,i} denote the number of CPU cycles for UE i𝑖i to execute the training of one data sample, δk,isubscript𝛿𝑘𝑖\delta_{k,i} denote the CPU-cycle frequency of UE i𝑖i. Then, the computation time of UE i𝑖i per local iteration can be expressed as follows [24],

Tcmptk,i=ck,i​Dk,iδk,i.superscriptsubscriptTcmp𝑡𝑘𝑖subscript𝑐𝑘𝑖subscript𝐷𝑘𝑖subscript𝛿𝑘𝑖\text{Tcmp}_{t}^{k,i}=\frac{c_{k,i}D_{k,i}}{\delta_{k,i}}. (11)

III-A2 Local Model Transmission

After UE i𝑖i updates its local model from 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t} to 𝐰t+1k,isuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘𝑖\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{k,i}, it will send the update to its edge server k𝑘k for edge model aggregation. In this paper, we adopt the Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiple Access (OFDMA) technique for local model transmission. Let btk,isuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑖b_{t}^{k,i} be the bandwidth matrix allocated to UE i𝑖i for its model transmission to edge server k𝑘k in round t𝑡t, then the achievable uplink rate of UE i𝑖i to edge server k𝑘k can be formulated as follows 111The adoption of SNR (signal-to-noise-ratio) rather than SINR (signal-to-interference-plus-noise-ratio) in this paper omits the consideration of inter-user interference caused by other users that are located in other service areas (ESs other than the considered ES). Nevertheless, it is easy to extend the situation from SNR to SINR. This is because only system parameters that can be measured by channel estimation methods are introduced [25]. Therefore, in this paper we use SNR rather than SINR for simplicity and cleanliness in the following sections.,

rtk,i=btk,i​log2⁡(1+pk,i​htk,ibtk,i​N0),∀k∈𝒦,i∈𝒩k,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑖subscript21subscript𝑝𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑖subscript𝑁0formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦𝑖subscript𝒩𝑘r_{t}^{k,i}=b_{t}^{k,i}\log_{2}\Big{(}1+\frac{p_{k,i}h_{t}^{k,i}}{b_{t}^{k,i}N_{0}}\Big{)},\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K},i\in\mathcal{N}_{k}, (12)

where pk,isubscript𝑝𝑘𝑖p_{k,i} is the transmit power of UE i𝑖i to edge server k𝑘k, htk,isuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡𝑘𝑖h_{t}^{k,i} is the channel gain between UE i𝑖i and edge server k𝑘k, and N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is the noise power.

Based on the uplink rate, we are now able to estimate the edge communication time between UE i𝑖i and server k𝑘k. Let Z𝑍Z be the data size of the model parameter, then the local model upload latency of UE i𝑖i in round t𝑡t can be computed by

Tcomtk,i=Zrtk,i,∀k∈𝒦,i∈𝒩k.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptTcom𝑡𝑘𝑖𝑍superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑘𝑖formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦𝑖subscript𝒩𝑘\text{Tcom}_{t}^{k,i}=\frac{Z}{r_{t}^{k,i}},\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K},i\in\mathcal{N}_{k}. (13)

III-B Edge Model Aggregation and Transmission

III-B1 Edge Model Aggregation

Once the models from local UEs have arrived, the edge server can aggregate them to update the edge model using the following formula,

𝐰t+1k=1nk​∑i=1nk𝐰t+1k,i.superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘1subscript𝑛𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘𝑖\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{k}=\frac{1}{n_{k}}\sum_{i=1}^{n_{k}}\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{k,i}. (14)

Note that in this paper, an ES is designed to aggragate local models synchronouly. UEs are randomly selected in each round to transmit their local updates until all selected UEs arrive at the ES for edge model aggragation. This is because the cover range of an ES is small, especially in 5G and B5G networks. For example, the cover range of a BS that supports millimeter Wave (mmWave) communication is usually around 100 m [26]. UEs are sparsely scattered within the coverage of each ES and it is convenient to schedule these UEs synchronously while training.

III-B2 Edge Model Transmission

Since there is no data training on edge servers, the computation time of model aggregation at edge servers is negligible. As long as 𝐰t+1ksuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{k} is generated, edge server k𝑘k will send it to the cloud server for global model aggregation. Let btk,0superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘0b_{t}^{k,0} be the bandwidth allocated to edge server k𝑘k for its model transmission to the cloud server in round t𝑡t, then the achievable uplink rate of edge server k𝑘k to the cloud server can be formulated as 222Here we also use SNR rather than SINR for simplicity and cleanliness in the following sections.

rtk,0=btk,0​log2⁡(1+pk,0​htk,0btk,0​N0),∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑘0superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘0subscript21subscript𝑝𝑘0superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡𝑘0superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘0subscript𝑁0for-all𝑘𝒦r_{t}^{k,0}=b_{t}^{k,0}\log_{2}\Big{(}1+\frac{p_{k,0}h_{t}^{k,0}}{b_{t}^{k,0}N_{0}}\Big{)},\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (15)

where pk,0subscript𝑝𝑘0p_{k,0} and hk,0subscriptℎ𝑘0h_{k,0} are the transmit power and channel gain of edge server k𝑘k to the cloud server, respectively. In consequence, the latency of uploading edge server k𝑘k’s model can be computed by

Tcomtk,0=Ztkrtk,0.superscriptsubscriptTcom𝑡𝑘0superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑘0\text{Tcom}_{t}^{k,0}=\frac{Z_{t}^{k}}{r_{t}^{k,0}}. (16)

Note that the data size transmitted by edge server k𝑘k in round t𝑡t is denoted as Ztksuperscriptsubscript𝑍𝑡𝑘Z_{t}^{k}, where Ztk≤Zsuperscriptsubscript𝑍𝑡𝑘𝑍Z_{t}^{k}\leq Z. This is because edge servers update the global model semi-asynchronously, and edge server k𝑘k does not have to transmit the entire model update during round t𝑡t.

III-C Cloud Aggregation

The cloud server aggregates updates from edge servers semi-asynchronously. That is, in each communication round, once the updates from A𝐴A ESs arrive at the cloud server, the CS would update the global model. Aggregating edge models semi-asynchronously is the result of the tradeoff between the latency and the training accuracy. On the one hand, if the CS aggregates the updates from ESs synchronously, the latency between ESs and the CS is determined by the latest ES that finishes its data transmission to the cloud. The long distance between ESs and the CS would make this latency unacceptable. On the other hand, if the CS aggregates the updates asynchronously, the learning algorithm may not converge due the staleness caused by those late ESs with out-of-date updates. As a result, for a massive mobile edge network that might suffer unacceptable long round latency as well as learning accuracy, we choose to aggregate edge models semi-asynchronously at the CS.

Given that the cloud server updates the global model in a semi-asynchronous manner, in order to characterize the scheduling policy of the ESs in each round, we introduce an indicator, πtk∈{0,1}superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘01\pi_{t}^{k}\in\{0,1\}, to denote whether the edge server k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} is selected in round t𝑡t to update the global model. Specifically, πtk=1superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘1\pi_{t}^{k}=1 means that ES k𝑘k is selected to update the global model in round t𝑡t, and πtk=0superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘0\pi_{t}^{k}=0 otherwise. For instance, consider the example shown in Fig. 2, there are four ESs in the system, and only two ESs are selected in each round to updating the global model at the cloud server. The computation has been carried out in 4 rounds and the ES scheduling decision vector 𝚷𝚷\mathbf{\Pi} in each round can be written as {1,1,0,0}1100\{1,1,0,0\}, {0,0,1,1}0011\{0,0,1,1\}, {0,1,0,1}0101\{0,1,0,1\} and {1,0,1,0}1010\{1,0,1,0\}, respectively.

Meanwhile, for the edge servers that are not selected in round t𝑡t but will be selected in later rounds, their updates are stale and may affect the convergence rate. We use τtksuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑡𝑘\tau_{t}^{k} to denote the interval between the current round t𝑡t and the last received global model version by ES k𝑘k. Such an interval reflects the staleness of edge updates. With this notion, the edge model received by the cloud server in round t𝑡t is denoted by 𝐰t−τtkksuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑡𝑘𝑘\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau_{t}^{k}}^{k}. As a result, the global model update at the cloud server in round t𝑡t can be rewritten as follows,

𝐰t+1=𝐰t−βA​∑k=1Kπtknk​∑i=1nk∇Fk,i​(𝐰t−τtk),subscript𝐰𝑡1subscript𝐰𝑡𝛽𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘subscript𝑛𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑘∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑡𝑘\mathbf{w}_{t+1}=\mathbf{w}_{t}-\frac{\beta}{A}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{\pi_{t}^{k}}{n_{k}}\sum_{i=1}^{n_{k}}\nabla F_{k,i}(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau_{t}^{k}}), (17)

where A=∑k=1Kπtk𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘A=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\pi_{t}^{k} denotes the number of selected ESs in each round. Besides, we use 𝒜tsubscript𝒜𝑡\mathcal{A}_{t} to denote the set of ESs selected to update the global model in round t𝑡t.

At the beginning of the next round t+1𝑡1t+1, the cloud server will send the updated global model 𝐰t+1subscript𝐰𝑡1\mathbf{w}_{t+1} back to all ESs, which are further forwarded to all UEs. The downlink broadcasting time consumed by this process is much smaller than the uplink transmission time since the transmit power of upper layers is much higher than that of lower layers, thereby being ignored for simplification [24, 27]. At this point, we can compute the total round latency of an HPFL system. The total round latency consists of two parts. The first part is the time consumed by the local model update, transmission, and aggregation between UEs and their ES k𝑘k. The duration of this part is determined by the slowest UE within the coverage of ES k𝑘k, which is equal to maxi∈𝒩k⁡{Tcomtk,i+Tcmptk,i}subscript𝑖subscript𝒩𝑘superscriptsubscriptTcom𝑡𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscriptTcmp𝑡𝑘𝑖\max_{i\in\mathcal{N}_{k}}\{\text{Tcom}_{t}^{k,i}+\text{Tcmp}_{t}^{k,i}\}. The second part is the time consumed by the edge model update, transmission, and aggregation between edge servers and the cloud server, which equals Tcomtk,0superscriptsubscriptTcom𝑡𝑘0\text{Tcom}_{t}^{k,0}. As a result, the total round latency of ES k𝑘k, which is denoted as Otksuperscriptsubscript𝑂𝑡𝑘O_{t}^{k}, is computed by

Otk=maxi∈𝒩k⁡{Tcmptk,i+Tcomtk,i}+Tcomtk,0.superscriptsubscript𝑂𝑡𝑘subscript𝑖subscript𝒩𝑘superscriptsubscriptTcmp𝑡𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscriptTcom𝑡𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscriptTcom𝑡𝑘0O_{t}^{k}=\max_{i\in\mathcal{N}_{k}}\{\text{Tcmp}_{t}^{k,i}+\text{Tcom}_{t}^{k,i}\}+\text{Tcom}_{t}^{k,0}. (18)

Note that here we also omit the consideration of aggregation time. This is because compared with the data computation time, the aggregation time is too short to be noticed. At this point, in accordance with the principle of semi-asynchronous learning, the total round latency is determined by the slowest selected ES in that round, i.e., Ot=maxk∈𝒦⁡{πtk​Otk}subscript𝑂𝑡subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑂𝑡𝑘O_{t}=\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\{\pi_{t}^{k}O_{t}^{k}\}.

IV Problem Formulation

For massive MEC networks, it is desirable to attain a fast convergence for the learning process. Therefore, in each round, our goal for the cloud server is to aggregate updates from as many ESs as possible. However, the more ESs that are selected, the longer round latency is likely to be. As a result, we try to find a tradeoff between the amount of information uploaded by the selected ESs in a certain round and the round latency, which is formalized as follows 333Besides bandwidth allocation and UE scheduling policy, other decision variables such like transmit power can also be included in the problem formulation. The logic keeps the same, but the parameters that need to be considered might change. Problem (P1) shows the case when we consider the bandwidth allocation and UE scheduling policy as variables, and it is free for the researchers to extend this general formulation to other forms.,

min𝚷,𝐛k,i,𝐛k,0subscript𝚷subscript𝐛𝑘𝑖subscript𝐛𝑘0\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{\Pi},\mathbf{b}_{k,i},\mathbf{b}_{k,0}}\quad −ρ​(F​(𝐰t+1)−F​(𝐰t))+(1−ρ)​maxk∈𝒦⁡{πtk​Otk}𝜌𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡1𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡1𝜌subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑂𝑡𝑘\displaystyle-\rho(F(\mathbf{w}_{t+1})-F(\mathbf{w}_{t}))+(1-\rho)\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\{\pi_{t}^{k}O_{t}^{k}\} (P1)
s.t. πtk={0,1},∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘01for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\pi_{t}^{k}=\{0,1\},\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K} (C1)
∑k=1K∑i=1nkbti,k+∑k=1Kbtk,0≤B,superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘0𝐵\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sum_{i=1}^{n_{k}}b_{t}^{i,k}+\sum_{k=1}^{K}b_{t}^{k,0}\leq B, (C2)

where 𝐛k,isubscript𝐛𝑘𝑖\mathbf{b}_{k,i} denotes the bandwidth allocation matrix between UE i∈𝒩k𝑖subscript𝒩𝑘i\in\mathcal{N}_{k} and ES k𝑘k, while 𝐛k,0subscript𝐛𝑘0\mathbf{b}_{k,0} denotes the bandwidth allocation vector between ES k𝑘k and CS 00. Meanwhile, 𝚷≜{πt1,πt2,…,πtk}≜𝚷superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡2…superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘\mathbf{\Pi}\triangleq\{\pi_{t}^{1},\pi_{t}^{2},\dots,\pi_{t}^{k}\} is the ES scheduling decision vector in round t𝑡t. ρ∈[0,1]𝜌01\rho\in[0,1] is the weight factor that controls the tradeoff between data importance and round latency. The first constraint (C1) indicates that πtksuperscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘\pi_{t}^{k} is a binary variable. The second constraint (C2) stipulates that the overall bandwidth allocated to the data transmission between UE and ES layers and between ES and CS layers shall not surpass B𝐵B. The third constraint (C3) shows that the bandwidth allocation is no smaller than 00.

V Convergence Analysis

Before solving the optimization problem, we first analyze the convergence rate of HPFL. This will offer insights into the key parameters that affect the value of training loss drop (i.e., F​(𝐰t+1)−F​(𝐰t)𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡1𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡F(\mathbf{w}_{t+1})-F(\mathbf{w}_{t})) as well as assisting us in transforming the objective of the HPFL optimization problem (P1) to a tractable form.

V-A Assumptions

In this paper, we consider the non-convex loss functions. To make the convergence analysis consistent with that of PFL, we make the following assumptions [16].

Assumption 1 (Bounded Staleness).

All delay variables τtksuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑡𝑘\tau_{t}^{k}’s are bounded, i.e., maxk∈𝒦⁡τtk≤Ssubscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑡𝑘𝑆\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\tau_{t}^{k}\leq S.

From Theorem 1, we obtain the upper bound of F​(𝐰t+1)−F​(𝐰t)𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡1𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡F(\mathbf{w}_{t+1})-F(\mathbf{w}_{t}), and the objective to minimize F​(𝐰t+1)−F​(𝐰t)𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡1𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡F(\mathbf{w}_{t+1})-F(\mathbf{w}_{t}) can be approximated to minimize its upper bound. If we ignore the constant terms in the upper bound, the original objective function of the optimization problem (P1) can be recast as

min𝚷,𝐛k,i,𝐛k,0−ρ​ϕ​∑k∈𝒦πtk​‖∇F​(𝐰t−τtk)‖2+(1−ρ)​maxk∈𝒦⁡{πtk​Otk}subscript𝚷subscript𝐛𝑘𝑖subscript𝐛𝑘0𝜌italic-ϕsubscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑡𝑘21𝜌subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑂𝑡𝑘\min_{\mathbf{\Pi},\mathbf{b}_{k,i},\mathbf{b}_{k,0}}\quad-\rho\phi\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\pi_{t}^{k}\|\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau_{t}^{k}})\|^{2}+(1-\rho)\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\{\pi_{t}^{k}O_{t}^{k}\} (30)

Using this transformed objective, we can optimize values of 𝚷𝚷\mathbf{\Pi}, 𝐛k,isubscript𝐛𝑘𝑖\mathbf{b}_{k,i}, and 𝐛k,0subscript𝐛𝑘0\mathbf{b}_{k,0} in the HPFL optimization problem (P1).

Notably, the term that matters in the upper bound, ϕ​∑k=1Kπtk​‖∇F​(𝐰t−τtk)‖2italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑡𝑘2\phi\sum_{k=1}^{K}\pi_{t}^{k}\|\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau_{t}^{k}})\|^{2}, is the secondary moment of local gradient-norm-value (GNV) of ES k𝑘k. This form of GNV is widely adopted as a measure of data importance indicating the amount of information provided by the local datasets [11]. Therefore, the transformed objective function (30) can be regarded as the tradeoff between the total data importance aggregated by the CS in each round and the round latency.

VI Joint Edge Server Scheduling and Bandwidth Allocation

This section details the steps to solve the optimization problem (P1). In particular, we decouple (P1) into two subproblems, the ES selection problem and bandwidth allocation problem, and then solve the two subproblems separately.

VI-A Problem Decoupling

Using the results from the convergence analysis, the optimization problem (P1) of HPFL can be approximatively transformed into the following optimization problem,

min𝚷,𝐛k,i,𝐛k,0⁡subscript𝚷subscript𝐛𝑘𝑖subscript𝐛𝑘0\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{\Pi},\mathbf{b}_{k,i},\mathbf{b}_{k,0}}\text{ } −ρ​ϕ​∑k∈𝒦πtk​‖∇F​(𝐰t−τtk)‖2𝜌italic-ϕsubscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑡𝑘2\displaystyle-\rho\phi\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\pi_{t}^{k}\|\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau_{t}^{k}})\|^{2}
+(1−ρ)​maxk∈𝒦⁡{πtk​Otk}1𝜌subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑂𝑡𝑘\displaystyle+(1-\rho)\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\{\pi_{t}^{k}O_{t}^{k}\} (P2)
s.t. (C​1)−(C​3).C1C3\displaystyle(\text{C}1)-(\text{C}3).

In order to solve (P2), we use the Coordinate Descent [28] method. To be more concrete, in each round, we first consider the bandwidth allocation 𝐛k,isubscript𝐛𝑘𝑖\mathbf{b}_{k,i}, 𝐛k,0subscript𝐛𝑘0\mathbf{b}_{k,0} as constants and then compute the optimal edge server scheduling policy. Then, we use the obtained edge server selection 𝚷𝚷\mathbf{\Pi} to compute the bandwidth allocation that can be used in the next round. As a result, we decouple the optimization problem (P2) into two subproblems: edge server selection problem (P3) and bandwidth allocation problem (P4). For a given set of bandwidth, the edge server selection problem can be formalized as follows,

min𝚷subscript𝚷\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{\Pi}}\quad −ρ​ϕ​∑k∈𝒦πtk​‖∇F​(𝐰t−τtk)‖2+(1−ρ)​maxk∈𝒦⁡{πtk​Otk}.𝜌italic-ϕsubscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑡𝑘21𝜌subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑂𝑡𝑘\displaystyle-\rho\phi\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\pi_{t}^{k}\|\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau_{t}^{k}})\|^{2}+(1-\rho)\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\{\pi_{t}^{k}O_{t}^{k}\}. (P3)
s.t. (C​1).C1\displaystyle(\text{C}1).

With a given ES selection policy, the bandwidth allocation problem is formalized as follows,

min𝐛k,i,𝐛k,0subscriptsubscript𝐛𝑘𝑖subscript𝐛𝑘0\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{b}_{k,i},\mathbf{b}_{k,0}}\quad maxk∈𝒦⁡{πtk​Otk}subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑂𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\{\pi_{t}^{k}O_{t}^{k}\} (P4)
s.t. (C​2)−(C​3).C2C3\displaystyle(\text{C}2)-(\text{C}3).

From the above analysis, we find that it is easy to determine the optimal value of πtksuperscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡𝑘\pi_{t}^{k}, as long as we obtain the values of ρ​‖∇F​(𝐰t−τtk)‖2𝜌superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑡𝑘2\rho\|\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau_{t}^{k}})\|^{2} and (1−ρ)​Otk1𝜌superscriptsubscript𝑂𝑡𝑘(1-\rho)O_{t}^{k}. For a given set of bandwidth allocation, what we need to do is to compute and compare the above two values for each of the ESs, and then determine whether an ES is to be scheduled in this round or not. This makes it easy and fast for practical implementation of ES selection. The pseudo-code of the ES scheduling algorithm is detailed in Alg. 1, and it is named ESScheduling. The ESScheduling algorithm is deployed at the CS since it requires global information (i.e., the global model and the round latency). Meanwhile, it requires O​(K)𝑂𝐾O(K) work every time it is triggered.

VI-C Bandwidth Allocation

After obtaining the optimal edge server scheduling policy 𝚷∗superscript𝚷\mathbf{\Pi}^{*}, we proceed to solve the bandwidth allocation problem (P4). G𝐺G can be regarded as the round latency between a edge server k𝑘k and its local UEs. We introduce the following theorem to explore relationship between btk,isuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑖b_{t}^{k,i} and G𝐺G.

Theorem 2.

When an edge server updates its edge model 𝐰tksuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘\mathbf{w}_{t}^{k} after receiving nksubscript𝑛𝑘n_{k} gradients from all its UEs, the optimal bandwidth allocation at the edge 𝐛tk,isuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑡𝑘𝑖\mathbf{b}_{t}^{k,i} can be achieved if and only if all these UEs have the same finishing time. That is, the optimal edge bandwidth allocation btk,isuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑖b_{t}^{k,i} between edge server k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} and the UEs under its coverage is achieved if and only if G1=G2=⋯=GNk=Gsubscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2⋯subscript𝐺subscript𝑁𝑘𝐺G_{1}=G_{2}=\dots=G_{N_{k}}=G, where Gi=Tcomtk,i+Tcmptk,isubscript𝐺𝑖superscriptsubscriptTcom𝑡𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscriptTcmp𝑡𝑘𝑖G_{i}=\text{Tcom}_{t}^{k,i}+\text{Tcmp}_{t}^{k,i} is the round latency between edge server k𝑘k and one of its UE i𝑖i, and G=maxi∈𝒩k⁡Gi𝐺subscript𝑖subscript𝒩𝑘subscript𝐺𝑖G=\max_{i\in\mathcal{N}_{k}}G_{i}.

Proof:

Therefore, rtk,isuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑘𝑖r_{t}^{k,i} monotonically increases with btk,isuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑖b_{t}^{k,i}. Given the relationship between rtk,isuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑘𝑖r_{t}^{k,i} and Tcomtk,isuperscriptsubscriptTcom𝑡𝑘𝑖\text{Tcom}_{t}^{k,i} shown in (13), it is clear that the Tcomk,itsuperscriptsubscriptabsent𝑡𝑘𝑖{}_{t}^{k,i} is monotonically decreases with btk,isuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑖b_{t}^{k,i}. As a result, at round t𝑡t, if any UE i∈𝒩k𝑖subscript𝒩𝑘i\in\mathcal{N}_{k} has finished its local model update process faster than the other UEs under the coverage of the same edge server k𝑘k, we can decrease its bandwidth allocation to make up for the other slower UEs j𝑗j (j∈𝒩k,j≠iformulae-sequence𝑗subscript𝒩𝑘𝑗𝑖j\in\mathcal{N}_{k},j\neq i). The decrease of btk,isuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑖b_{t}^{k,i} leads to the increase of Tcomk,itsuperscriptsubscriptabsent𝑡𝑘𝑖{}_{t}^{k,i}, and further, to the increase of Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}. Meanwhile, the increase of btk,jsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑗b_{t}^{k,j} leads to the decrease of Tcomk,jtsuperscriptsubscriptabsent𝑡𝑘𝑗{}_{t}^{k,j}, and further, to the decease of Gjsubscript𝐺𝑗G_{j}. In this way, G𝐺G can be reduced since it is determined by the slowest UE in 𝒩ksubscript𝒩𝑘\mathcal{N}_{k}. Such a bandwidth compensation is performed until all UEs in 𝒩ksubscript𝒩𝑘\mathcal{N}_{k} finish their data transportation with edge server k𝑘k at the same time. That is, the optimal bandwidth allocation btk,isuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑖b_{t}^{k,i} between UE i∈𝒩k𝑖subscript𝒩𝑘i\in\mathcal{N}_{k} and edge server k𝑘k is achieved when all UEs have the same Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}, and G=Gi𝐺subscript𝐺𝑖G=G_{i}. ∎

Let btk=∑i=1nkbtk,isuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑖b_{t}^{k}=\sum_{i=1}^{n_{k}}b_{t}^{k,i}, then according to [24], the optimal bandwidth allocation of btk,isuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑖b_{t}^{k,i} is computed as follows,

btk,i=btk​Z​ln⁡2(G∗​(Π)−Tcmptk,i)​(W​(−Γtk,i​e−Γtk,i)+Γtk,i),superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑍2superscript𝐺ΠsuperscriptsubscriptTcmp𝑡𝑘𝑖𝑊superscriptsubscriptΓ𝑡𝑘𝑖superscript𝑒superscriptsubscriptΓ𝑡𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscriptΓ𝑡𝑘𝑖b_{t}^{k,i}=b_{t}^{k}\frac{Z\ln 2}{(G^{*}(\Pi)-\text{Tcmp}_{t}^{k,i})(W(-\Gamma_{t}^{k,i}e^{-\Gamma_{t}^{k,i}})+\Gamma_{t}^{k,i})}, (43)

where Γtk,i≜N0​Z​ln⁡2(G∗​(Π)−Tcmptk,i)​pk,i​htk,i≜superscriptsubscriptΓ𝑡𝑘𝑖subscript𝑁0𝑍2superscript𝐺ΠsuperscriptsubscriptTcmp𝑡𝑘𝑖subscript𝑝𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡𝑘𝑖\Gamma_{t}^{k,i}\triangleq\frac{N_{0}Z\ln 2}{(G^{*}(\Pi)-\text{Tcmp}_{t}^{k,i})p_{k,i}h_{t}^{k,i}}, W​(⋅)𝑊⋅W(\cdot) is Lamber-W function, and G∗​(Π)superscript𝐺ΠG^{*}(\Pi) is the objective value of (P7).

Meanwhile, from Theorem 2, we can immediately draw the following corollary.

Corollary 1.

Tcomtk,0superscriptsubscriptTcom𝑡𝑘0\text{Tcom}_{t}^{k,0} monotonically decreases with btk,0superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘0b_{t}^{k,0}. That is, as for the communication between edge servers and the cloud server, the optimal bandwidth allocation can only be achieved if and only if all the scheduled edge servers have the same finishing time.

At this moment, the relationship between btksuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘b_{t}^{k}, btk,isuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑖b_{t}^{k,i} and the optimal value G∗​(𝚷)superscript𝐺𝚷G^{*}(\mathbf{\Pi}) is clear. Similarly, the relationship between btk,0superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘0b_{t}^{k,0} and Tcomtk,0superscriptsubscriptTcom𝑡𝑘0\text{Tcom}_{t}^{k,0} is clear. As a result, (P7) can be regarded as an optimization problem with respect to G∗superscript𝐺G^{*} and Tcomtk,0superscriptsubscriptTcom𝑡𝑘0\text{Tcom}_{t}^{k,0}. This is a typical min-max optimization problem, which can be solved using the well-known progressive filling [29] algorithm. More specifically, in order to solve the optimization problem (P7), we increase the value of G𝐺G and Tcomtk,0superscriptsubscriptTcom𝑡𝑘0\text{Tcom}_{t}^{k,0} at the same speed until (C2), the bandwidth constraint, has been violated. To translate this process with respect to btk,isuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑖b_{t}^{k,i} and btk,0superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘0b_{t}^{k,0}, what we need to do to solve (P7) is to increase btk,isuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘𝑖b_{t}^{k,i} and btk,0superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘0b_{t}^{k,0} at a rate such that G𝐺G and Tcomtk,0superscriptsubscriptTcom𝑡𝑘0\text{Tcom}_{t}^{k,0} can increase at the same speed until the available bandwidth B𝐵B has been fully occupied. The pseudo-code of the bandwidth allocation mechanism is detailed in Alg. 2, and it is named BandwidthAllocation. The BandwidthAllocation algorithm is also deployed at the CS since it requires global information to have the bandwidth between ESs and its UEs as well as the bandwidth between the CS and the ESs allocated. Given that BandwidthAllocation uses the progressive filling method, it requires to sort the current bandwidth of the UEs and the ESs. Therefore, the computation complexity of BandwidthAllocation can be coarsely regarded as O​(log⁡K)𝑂𝐾O(\log K) [30].

VI-D The HPFL algorithm

With the obtained ES scheduling policy and bandwidth allocation mechanism, we can now implement HPFL over MEC networks. Alg. 3 shows the pseudo-code of HPFL. In each communication round, HPFL first computes the bandwidth allocation 𝐛k,0superscript𝐛𝑘0\mathbf{b}^{k,0} and 𝐛k,isuperscript𝐛𝑘𝑖\mathbf{b}^{k,i} with the ES scheduling vector 𝚷𝚷\mathbf{\Pi} derived from the last round. Then, based on the bandwidth allocation, each ES can decide whether it needs to be scheduled in the current round or not. With the obtained scheduling policy 𝚷𝚷\mathbf{\Pi}, HPFL determines the set of ESs contributing to the global model update in this round. Other edge models must be patient until they are called in the next rounds, whether their updates are fresh or stale.

VII Performance Evaluation

In this section, we conduct experiments to (i) verify that HPFL can provide convergent training loss, (ii) demonstrate that there exists a tradeoff between the maximum round data importance and minimum round latency in HPFL, and (iii) check the price HPFL pays for its gain in saving the round latency as well as its benefits in capturing more important data.

VII-A Setup

VII-A1 Datasets and Models

We consider a hierarchical system with one central cloud server and 20 edge servers, each covering an area with 10 UEs. It is desired for the learner to pick up 151515 ESs in each round, that is, A=15𝐴15A=15. We consider the channel gains htk,i=oi​dk,i−2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡𝑘𝑖subscript𝑜𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖2h_{t}^{k,i}=o_{i}d_{k,i}^{-2} and htk,0=ok​dk,0−2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑡𝑘0subscript𝑜𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘02h_{t}^{k,0}=o_{k}d_{k,0}^{-2} follow the Rayleigh distribution where oi=−36subscript𝑜𝑖36o_{i}=-36dB and ok=−40subscript𝑜𝑘40o_{k}=-40dB are the Rayleigh fading parameters, dk,isubscript𝑑𝑘𝑖d_{k,i} is the actual distance between UE i𝑖i and ES k𝑘k that is uniformly generated between [2,50]250[2,50] m, and dk,0subscript𝑑𝑘0d_{k,0} is the actual distance between ES k𝑘k and BS 00 that is uniformly generated between [50,200]50200[50,200] m. We conduct the experiments using two datasets: MNIST [31] and CIFAR-10 [32]. The network model for MNIST is a 2-layer deep neural network (DNN) with a hidden layer of size 100, while the network model for CIFAR-10 is LeNet-5 [33] that has two convolutional layers and three fully connected layers. The other parameters we use are summarized in Table I. All experiments are conducted by PyTorch [34] version 1.11.0.

VII-A2 Dataset Participation

The level of divergence in the distribution of UEs’ datasets will affect the overall performance of the system. To reflect this feature, each UE is allocated a different local data size and has l=1,2​…,10𝑙12…10l=1,2\dots,10 of the 10 labels. where l𝑙l indicates the level of data heterogeneity. The higher l𝑙l is, the more heterogenous the datasets are.

VII-A3 Baselines

To examine the effectiveness of HPFL, we compare it with one baseline algorithm in different ES selection modes. Specifically, we compare HPFL with the Hierarchical Federated Learning (HFL) algorithm when ESs are selected in the mode we proposed in this paper, fully selected and randomly selected. In brief, we compare the performance of HPFL with five other algorithms, namely, HFL with the proposed ES selection mode, HFL with fully selected ESs, HFL with randomly selected ESs, HPFL with fully selected ESs, and HPFL with randomly selected ESs.

VII-A4 Performance Metrics

For the convergence performance, we measure the training loss as well as the test accuracy of the algorithms. The smaller the training loss is, the better the algorithm behaves. On the contrary, the larger the test accuracy is, the better the algorithm behaves. Meanwhile, for the implementation performance of HPFL over MEC networks, we measure HPFL’s round latency and its total data importance collected in each round. We also measure the runtime of implementing HPFL in MEC networks compared with intuitive algorithms with no needs to compute the ES scheduling policy and bandwidth allocation.

VII-B Convergence Performance

We begin with evaluating the convergence performance of the six algorithms: HFL and HPFL with fully selected ESs, randomly selected ESs and the proposed ES selection mode, respectively. Fig. 3 illustrates the convergence performance of the six algorithms under the MNIST dataset, while Fig. 4 shows the same convergence performance using the CIFAR-10 dataset. From both figures, we observe that the algorithms with fully selected ESs always outperform the others. This aligns with our intuition as all-in training provides information about all ESs and all UEs. We also notice that the algorithms with randomly selected ESs behave the worst. This is also a reasonable result because ESs that are randomly selected can not always provide the most effective information for the global model training. Meanwhile, all the HPFL algorithms outperform the HFL algorithms since the HPFL always behaves well in dealing with heterogeneous datasets. This result provides another proof of PFL’s advantage in fast convergence, even though it is implemented using hierarchical aggregations.

For the MNIST dataset, it is a simple dataset that is easy to train. Therefore, if HPFL performs well, its behavior should be pretty close to the optimal one, where all ESs are selected in each communication round. The results shown in Fig. 3 just prove the above point, that the proposed ES scheduling scheme gives almost the same result as the fully selected ES scheme. Moreover, as we can observe from Fig. 4 where the CIFAR-10 dataset is considered, the convergence performance of algorithms with fully selected ESs is more stable than that of algorithms with the proposed ES selection method and the randomly selected ESs, while the algorithms with randomly selected ESs behave the worst. This is a reasonable result, that an all-in UE selection mode contains data information from all UEs, whereas a randomly UE selection mode may leave out important data information. Besides, algorithms with the proposed ES selection method attempt to pick up the UEs with more data importance in each rounds, thereby leading to a convergence performance in between.

A detailed statistics breakdown is given in Fig. 5 and Fig. 6. These two figures show the convergence performance of the proposed HPFL under different values of ρ𝜌\rho, i.e., ρ=0.1,0.3,0.5,0.9𝜌0.10.30.50.9\rho=0.1,0.3,0.5,0.9. We observe that the higher the value of ρ𝜌\rho is, the better the algorithm’s training loss and test accuracy are. We attribute this phenomenon to the impact of ρ𝜌\rho, that when ρ𝜌\rho increases, HPFL is inclined to choose ESs with higher data importance. Therefore, the HPFL’s convergence behavior under higher values of ρ𝜌\rho would be better.

VII-C Average Round Latency vs Total Data Importance

In this subsection, we examine the HPFL average round latency and total data importance captured in each round with respect to the number of communication rounds and the weight factor ρ𝜌\rho, respectively.

VII-C1 Effect of the communication round

From Fig. 7b, we observe that both average round latency and total data importance decrease as the number of rounds increases. This is because the objective of HPFL is to minimize the round latency and the round training loss. Both optimal round latency and optimal total data importance captured in each round are bound to continuously decrease as the round number increases. Such a decline slows down as HPFL converges, as it is shown in Fig. 7b.

VII-C2 Effect of the weight factor ρ𝜌\rho

Next, we investigate the effect of ρ𝜌\rho on the average round time and the total data importance captured in each round. Due to space concerns, we only used the MNIST dataset to do the experiments. The value of ρ𝜌\rho changes from 0.40.40.4 to 0.80.80.8 under the step of 0.050.050.05, and the results are measured when the HPFL algorithms converge, which are shown in Fig. 8. We observe that for HPFL algorithms with fully selected and randomly selected UEs, both metrics remain unchanged under various weight factors. However, as for the HPFL algorithm with the proposed ES selected mode, the average round latency and the total data importance captured in each round increase as the value of ρ𝜌\rho increases. This is a reasonable result because, as the weight factor increases, it is desired for the scheduler to choose ESs with larger total data importance. Therefore, as we can see in Fig. 8b, the larger ρ𝜌\rho is, the more total data importance gathered in each round. At the same time, as the HPFL’s objective function indicates, more selected data importance means larger round latency, and the result shown in Fig. 8 exactly verifies this point of view.

VII-C3 Effect of the heterogenous factor l𝑙l

Now we come to explore the effect of the heterogenous level l𝑙l on the learning performance of HPFL. The results are shown in Fig. 9 and 10. From both datasets we observe that the larger the heterogenous level l𝑙l is, the poorer convergence performances are. This phenomenon is more pronounced in the CIFAR-10 dataset than that in the MNIST dataset. This result shows that the more complicated the dataset is, the difference between UEs with different levels of heterogeneity is more obvious.

VII-D Algorithm Runtime Performance

Finally, we check the price HPFL pays for its gains in saving round latencies and its advantages in selecting ESs with more data importance. We compare the runtime of HPFL and a simple hierarchical PFL algorithm, where ESs are also scheduled semi-asynchronously but randomly selected, whereas the bandwidth is equally divided, namely, btk,1=btk,2=⋯=btk,nksuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘2⋯superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘subscript𝑛𝑘b_{t}^{k,1}=b_{t}^{k,2}=\dots=b_{t}^{k,n_{k}}, and btk,0=btj,0superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑘0superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑡𝑗0b_{t}^{k,0}=b_{t}^{j,0} (k≠j,k,j∈𝒜t)formulae-sequence𝑘𝑗𝑘𝑗subscript𝒜𝑡(k\neq j,k,j\in\mathcal{A}_{t}). We name this simple hierarchical PFL algorithm as SHPFL. Meanwhile, the runtime is measured as the average duration when BandwidthAllocation and ESScheduling algorithms are triggered in each round. There is no need for SHPFL to compute the ES scheduling policy and the bandwidth allocation problem. Therefore, as shown in Fig. 11a, as the number of selected ESs increases, the average runtime of SHPFL in each round keeps constant, while that of HPFL grows linearly. Moreover, the average runtime in each round of HPFL algorithms is at least 60×60\times larger than that of SHPFL. This indicates that to save more round latency and capture more data information, HPFL sacrifices its runtime for better convergence and implementation performance. Nevertheless, the consumed runtime (in tens of milliseconds) of our proposed HPFL is acceptable since it is much smaller than the average round time (in tens of seconds).

Fig. 11b shows the tradeoff between average round runtime and the training loss drop along with the communication rounds. It is obvious that for the proposed HPFL algorithm, the average round runtime and the training loss drop are positively correlated. This is a reasonable result, since as the communication rounds increases, the training loss drop decreases. According to the ES scheduling algorithm, the number of selected ESs in each round decreases with the decreasing of the training loss drop, thereby leading to the reduction of average round runtime. However, for the SHPFL algorithm, the average round runtime does not change and has no relationship witht eh training loss drop. This is also a reasonable result, since there is no need for SHPFL to compute the ES scheduling policy and the bandwidth allocation problem.

VIII Conclusions

In this paper, we have studied the hierarchical PFL mechanism for massive MEC networks. We have proposed HPFL, a hierarchical PFL algorithm that adapts quickly to individual UEs with hierarchical aggregations. HPFL is implemented in a three-layer MEC network, where ESs aggregates the edge models synchronously, and the CS fuses the global model update in a semi-asynchronous manner. The semi-asynchronous aggregation at the CS brings a tradeoff between the round training loss and the round latency. HPFL combines the objectives of training loss maximization and round latency minimization while determining the ES scheduling policy and bandwidth allocation. This optimization problem is solved by firstly analyzing the convergence of HPFL, thus transforming the problem into a tractable one. Then, we decoupled the problem into an ES scheduling problem and a bandwidth allocation problem, and solved them separately. The extensive experimental results demonstrated that not only HPFL is convergent, but provides a tradeoff in maximizing the round training loss and minimizing the round latency.

As a result, the desired upper bound is obtained.
